welcome.title: Welcome to UDOIT
welcome.description: UDOIT helps you through the process of removing accessibility barriers in your online course content.
welcome.scan: Find accessibility barriers quickly with an automated scan.
welcome.fix: Fix issues easily with simple tools and just-in-time instructions.
welcome.report: Make steady progress with small daily goals and easy reporting tools.
summary.title: Accessibility Summary
summary.description: Removing accessibility barriers is an ongoing process, not a one-time project. UDOIT helps you track your progress and make steady improvements.
summary.issues.description: Issues are known accessibility barriers that are most likely to directly impact users.
summary.potentials.description: Potential issues may be fine, but should be reviewed to ensure they don't present accessibility barriers.
summary.suggestions.description: Suggestions are ways to improve your course content for ease of use, but are not required.
report.header.name: Name
report.msg.no_results: Try changing the filters or searching with a different keyword
fix.msg.resolved: If you have reviewed this issue and determined that it is not an accessibility barrier, you can mark it as resolved.
fix.msg.unresolved: This issue has been marked as resolved. If additional changes need to be made, you can mark it as unresolved.
about.disclaimer: This tool is meant to be used as a guide, not a certification. It only checks for common accessibility issues, and is not comprehensive; a clean report in UDOIT does not necessarily mean that your course is fully accessible. Likewise, the tool may indicate a possible accessibility issue where one does not exist.

form.anchor_text.learn_more:
Link Text

Screen readers generate a list of all the links on a page for blind users to efficiently navigate to desired content. In this context, multiple “read more” links on a page will only confuse users. Meaningful stand-alone link text is also helpful for users with cognitive disabilities.

Best Practices

  • Provide clear and concise link text that can be understood out of context
  • Contextualize generic links such as “read more”

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Links and Hypertext
form.contrast.learn_more:
Color Contrast

Users with low vision need sufficient contrast in order to read. The color contrast ratio follows a formula to compare the luminance of the foreground text with background colors. Take note of contrast especially for text resizing, responsive design, and motion effects like parallax or animated backgrounds when the position of text on its background can change.

Best Practices

  • Make sure text achieves sufficient contrast against its background
  • Achieve minimum contrast for all text placed over images or gradients

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Contrast and Color Accessibility

Online Color Contrast Checker
form.file.pdf.learn_more:
Accessible PDF Files

Similar to web pages, PDF files can provide hidden "tags" which provide additional context for screen readers about the document structure and content. When saving or exporting PDFs, be sure to select the "tagged" option, if available. Untagged PDFs are not considered accessible.

Best Practices

  • Always save and export PDFs with tags to ensure accessibility.

For More Information

WebAIM.org: PDF Accessibility
form.file.doc.learn_more:
Accessible Word Documents

Word documents can be accessible if they are created using Word as it was designed, but many people don't use its built-in features properly. For instance, headings are accessible if created using Word's "Heading" styles. However, most users create headings by highlighting text and applying changes to fonts, sizes, and formatting. While these sections may visually look like headers, they are not part of the document structure that screen readers use to navigate.

Best Practices

  • Use built-in headings and lists; don't style text or change font settings yourself.
  • Use the built-in alt text tool for images.
  • Use the built-in table tools to create tables.
  • Use the built-in accessibility checker.

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Creating Accessible Documents
form.file.ppt.learn_more:
Accessible Presentations

When creating a slide show presentation, content should be clear and understandable for all learners. If the presentation will be viewed on a projector, make sure that text is not too small. If the file is meant to be downloaded, consider exporting it as a PDF, which has wider support.

Best Practices

  • Text and background colors should have high contrast.
  • Do not use color alone to convey information.
  • If available, use a built-in accessibility checker.

For More Information

WebAIM.org: PowerPoint Accessibility
form.file.xls.learn_more:
Accessible Excel Files

Spreadsheets are relatively easy to navigate for screenreaders, but can sometimes be visually overwhelming or difficult to read when text is too small or spaced too closely together. Using slightly larger fonts and adding visual space can help make spreadsheets easier to understand.

Best Practices

  • Add extra width and height to cells to enhance readability.
  • Remove or hide unnecessary blank rows and columns between sections of data.
  • Freeze rows and columns as necessary to ensure that headers are consistently visible.

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Optimizing Spreadsheet Accessibility
form.heading_empty.learn_more:
Heading Structure

Users who rely on screen readers depend heavily on headings to help them quickly understand and navigate page content. Organized headings create a clear outline of the page and allow users to find what they need quickly and easily.

Never create headings by styling text alone, like using larger or bolded fonts and colors. Screen readers don't distinguish between text of different sizes. Instead, use Heading elements, which not only style the text consistently, but allow screen readers to isolate and skip to headings as needed.

Headings can be thought of as indents on a written outline: the bigger the number, the further indented that portion of the outline would be. The first heading is H1, then H2, all the way to H6. A heading should never be more than one number higher (one level deeper) than the heading just before it.

Best Practices

  • Describe sections of content with accurate, succinct headings.
  • Never use styles alone to create headings: use Heading elements.
  • Every page should have 1 top-level heading (H1), which is usually the page title.
  • Every other heading should be H2 through H6. Avoid skipping levels.

For More Information:

WebAIM.org: Headings
form.heading_style.learn_more:
Heading Structure

Users who rely on screen readers depend heavily on headings to help them quickly understand and navigate page content. Organized headings create a clear outline of the page and allow users to find what they need quickly and easily.

Never create headings by styling text alone, like using larger or bolded fonts and colors. Screen readers don't distinguish between text of different sizes. Instead, use Heading elements, which not only style the text consistently, but allow screen readers to isolate and skip to headings as needed.

Headings can be thought of as indents on a written outline: the bigger the number, the further indented that portion of the outline would be. The first heading is H1, then H2, all the way to H6. A heading should never be more than one number higher (one level deeper) than the heading just before it.

Best Practices

  • Describe sections of content with accurate, succinct headings.
  • Never use styles alone to create headings: use Heading elements.
  • Every page should have 1 top-level heading (H1), which is usually the page title.
  • Every other heading should be H2 through H6. Avoid skipping levels.

For More Information:

WebAIM.org: Headings
form.sensory_misuse.learn_more:
Clear Instructions

When writing instructions, avoid using visual characteristics such as shape, size, or location. For instance, "Use the description on the RIGHT," "Select the BLUE option," or "Click the SQUARE button" can be problematic for users who cannot see an object or its location on the screen.

However, if the text is NOT instructions, this rule can be ignored, such as "RIGHT BELOW the surface..." or "LEFT to their own devices...".

Best Practices

  • Use instructions that don't depend on shape, size, or location.
  • Use a visible text label for the object or area described, like "The Delete Button on the Left".
form.table_headers.learn_more:
Table Headers

Data tables should have headers to help users understand the data. This is especially important for screen reader users, who may not be able to see the table layout. For simple tables, you can define the first row, first column, or both as headers. If your table is more complicated, you may need to use the scope attribute for headers or the headers attribute for cells to indicate which headers apply to which cells.

Best Practices

  • If a table is not for presenting data, identify it as a layout table.
  • Use the th element instead of td to define headers for rows and columns.

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Accessible Data Tables

W3.org: Tables Tutorial
form.review_only.learn_more: In order to fix this issue, you may need to edit the content in your LMS. Click on the name of the content to link directly to your LMS and save your changes there.
form.alt_text.msg.text_has_file_extensio: Alt text cannot contain file extensions
form.alt_text.msg.text_matches_filename: Alt text cannot match file name
form.aria_role.feedback.no_tag: The HTML tag could not be computed.
form.emphasis.msg.required: Text must be bold or italicized
rule.desc.AnchorLinksToMultiMediaRequire: Multimedia objects should be accompanied by a link to a transcript of the content.
rule.desc.AnchorLinksToSoundFilesNeedTra: Links to a sound file should be followed by a link to a transcript of the file.
rule.desc.AnchorMustContainText:
Link Text

Screen readers generate a list of all the links on a page for blind users to efficiently navigate to desired content. In this context, multiple “read more” links on a page will only confuse users. Meaningful stand-alone link text is also helpful for users with cognitive disabilities.

Best Practices

  • Provide clear and concise link text that can be understood out of context
  • Contextualize generic links such as “read more”

Learn more at WebAIM.org: Links and Hypertext
rule.desc.AnchorSuspiciousLinkText: Links should be descriptive of the content they're linking to, such as 'Class Schedule' rather than 'schedule.html' or 'click here'.
rule.desc.BaseFontIsNotUsed: The basefont tag is deprecated and should not be used. Investigate using stylesheets instead.
rule.desc.BlinkIsNotUsed: The blink tag should not be used. Ever.
rule.desc.BrokenLink: Links should be checked to ensure that they still function. This could be temporary, so please verify and repair the link if necessary.
rule.desc.ContentTooLong: For content longer than 3000 words, consider splitting it up into multiple documents. This makes it easier for students to process and retain the information.
rule.desc.CssTextHasContrast:
Color Contrast

Users with low vision need sufficient contrast in order to read. The color contrast ratio follows a formula to compare the luminance of the foreground text with background colors. Take note of contrast especially for text resizing, responsive design, and motion effects like parallax or animated backgrounds when the position of text on its background can change.

Best Practices

  • Make sure text achieves sufficient contrast against its background
  • Achieve minimum contrast for all text placed over images or gradients

Learn more at WebAIM.org: Contrast and Color Accessibility

Online Color Contrast Checker
rule.desc.CssTextStyleEmphasize: When emphasizing text, you may use color with sufficient contrast as long as you also apply some other form of emphasis, such as bold or italics. This ensures that screen reader users are aware of the text's importance.
rule.desc.DocumentReadingDirection: Changes in text direction in inline content should be indicated using any HTML element (for example, span) with a 'dir' attribute indicating left-to-right or right-to-left. For example, a Hebrew phrase within an english paragraph should have it's own text direction indicated.
rule.desc.EmbedTagDetected: Embedded content may not be properly viewable on mobile devices. Consider mobile users when relying on objects for multimedia content.
rule.desc.FontIsNotUsed: The font tag is deprecated and should not be used. Investigate using stylesheets instead.
rule.desc.HeadersHaveText: Sighted and screen reader users depend on headings to organize the content on the page. Headings should not be empty and should represent an accurate outline of the content
rule.desc.HeadingsInOrder: Nest headings by their rank (or level). The most important heading has the rank 1 (h1) in HTML files or rank 2 (h2) in Canvas pages, the least important heading has the rank 6 (h6). Headings with an equal or higher rank start a new section, headings with a lower rank start new subsections that are part of the higher ranked section. Skipping heading ranks can be confusing and should be avoided.
rule.desc.IframeNotHandled: Embedded content is not evaluated automatically by UDOIT. Please manually evaluate this content for accessibility issues and compatibility with mobile devices.
rule.desc.ImageAltIsDifferent:
Alternative Text (Alt Text) is an alternative (non-visual) way to describe the meaning of an image. Please provide a brief description of the image for a screen reader user. Note: It should not be the image file name and should be 125 characters or less.

Learn more at WebAIM.org: Alt Text Accessibility
rule.desc.ImageAltIsTooLong:
Alternative Text (Alt Text) is an alternative (non-visual) way to describe the meaning of an image. Please provide a brief description of the image for a screen reader user. Note: It should not be the image file name and should be 125 characters or less.

Learn more at WebAIM.org: Alt Text Accessibility
rule.desc.ImageAltNotEmptyInAnchor:
Alternative Text (Alt Text) is an alternative (non-visual) way to describe the meaning of an image. Please provide a brief description of the image for a screen reader user. Note: It should not be the image file name and should be 125 characters or less.

Learn more at WebAIM.org: Alt Text Accessibility
rule.desc.ImageAltNotPlaceholder:
Any image that is not used decoratively or which is purely for layout purposes cannot have an 'alt' attribute that consists solely of placeholders. Placeholders include: nbsp,  , spacer, image, img, and photo.

Learn more at WebAIM.org: Alt Text Accessibility
rule.desc.ImageHasAlt:
Alternative Text (Alt Text) is an alternative (non-visual) way to describe the meaning of an image. Please provide a brief description of the image for a screen reader user. Note: It should not be the image file name and should be 125 characters or less.

Learn more at WebAIM.org: Alt Text Accessibility
rule.desc.ImageHasAltDecorative:
This image was marked as decorative in the Rich Content Editor, but the ALT attribute contains text. Please remove the alternative text or the decorative marking.

Learn more at WebAIM.org: Alt Text Accessibility
rule.desc.ImageHasLongDescription: Any image that has an 'alt' attribute that does not fully convey the meaning of the image should have a 'longdesc' attribute.
rule.desc.InputImageNotDecorative: Every form image button which has text within the image (say, a picture of the word 'Search' in a special font), should have the same text within the 'alt' attribute.
rule.desc.MarqueeIsNotUsed: The marquee element is difficult for users to read and is not a standard HTML element. Try to find another way to convey the importance of this text.
rule.desc.NoHeadings: If appropriate, add headings to the page to organize the content for sighted and screen reader users. The headings should represent an accurate outline of the content
rule.desc.ObjectMustContainText: Multimedia objects should be accompanied by a link to a transcript of the content.
rule.desc.ObjectTagDetected: Multimedia embedded using the 'Object' tag may require the user to install a plugin for their web browser. This can create support and access issues for some users. Additionally, users on mobile devices may not be able to view the multimedia content at all. Consider using an alternative format that the user's browser can display natively.
rule.desc.ParagraphNotUsedAsHeader: Bold and Italics are used to emphasize text, whereas headings are used to define the structure of the document. Headings like h1-h6 are extremely useful for non-sighted users to navigate the structure of the page, and formatting a paragraph to just be big or bold, while it might visually look like a heading, does not make it one. UDOIT has flagged this as a potential usage of style for document structure, please ensure that this is not the case when you review the content in the HTML editor.
rule.desc.PreShouldNotBeUsedForTabularVa: If a pre element is used for tabular data, change the data to use a well-formed table.
rule.desc.RedirectedLink: When the address of a web page changes, the content owner may set up a redirect so that the link is not broken. However, that redirect could go away in the future, so it's best to update the link now. The real url has been populated into the form below.
rule.desc.TableDataShouldHaveTableHeader: Table headers provide a description of the table structure for sighted and screen reader users.
rule.desc.TableHeaderShouldHaveScope: Scope declarations in headers organize and define table data by row/column for sighted and screen reader users.
rule.desc.VideoCaptionsMatchCourseLangua:
While this video has captions, there are no captions available for your course language. While not imperative to fix, if you'd like to you have three options:

  • Contact the creator of the video and request captions in your course language be added.
  • Create captions yourself using a service like Amara (http://amara.org/).
  • Find a different video that has closed captioning for your course language.
rule.desc.VideoEmbedCheck: Videos used on online courses are required to have closed captioning. Unfortunately, some video services do not provide an API for checking captions and will need to be manually verified.
rule.desc.VideoProvidesCaptions: All video elements must have a caption using the track element with caption attribute. The caption should convey all meaningful information in the video element; this includes, but is not limited to, dialogue, musical cues, and sound effects. Good captions not only include dialogue, but also identify who is speaking and include non-speech information conveyed through sound, including meaningful sound effects.
rule.desc.VideosEmbeddedOrLinkedNeedCapt: Captions should be included in the video to provide dialogue to users who are hearing impaired. (Please note that videos that have been removed, deleted, or are Unlisted will also cause this error, and will need to be manually verified.)
rule.desc.VideosHaveAutoGeneratedCaption: Captions that are machine-generated by a service like YouTube are rarely if ever fully accurate and should not be relied upon for educational use.
rule.example.AnchorLinksToSoundFilesNeed:
Wrong
<a href='interview.mp3'>Listen to the interview</a>
Right
<a href='interview.mp3'>Listen to the interview</a> <a href='transcript.html'>(transcript)</a>
rule.example.ImageAltNotPlaceholder:
Wrong

<img src='dog.jpg' alt='image'>

Right

<img src='dog.jpg' alt='A photograph of a dog'>
rule.example.ImageHasLongDescription:
Wrong

<img src='complexImage.png' alt='A complex image that cannot be described succinctly.'>

Right

<img src='complexImage.png' alt='A complex image that cannot be described succinctly.' longdesc='longer_description.html'>
rule.example.InputImageNotDecorative:
Wrong

<input type='image' src='search.png' alt='A pretty picture'/>

Right

<input type='image' src='search.png' alt='Search this site'/>
rule.example.MarqueeIsNotUsed:
Wrong

<marquee>This is really hard to read</marquee>

Right

<strong>This is much easier to read</strong>
